answers.answer: Unfortunately, these autoimmune diseases like to bring friends.  Many of us end up having more than 1.  Spondy changes in your back could indicate another condition there.  Have you gotten a second opinion?  If not, I think it is time to do so.  It may be that you will have to consider one of the more aggressive drugs to get your condition(s) under control.  If it is RA or one of the spondylotharapys, they will likely want to treat you with plaquenil and possibly methotrexate or even humira or enbrel.  You will have to investigate the medications, there side effects and consider all the ways your condition effects your life and decide what is best for you.  Please get a second (or third or fifth or seventh) opinion and let us know what you find out.

question: I have been told I have fibromyalgia and hypothyroid and osteoarthritus  and diabetes. Today rheumotologist told me the lab in california did my test and it was 179 Is that high  and that my problem is I have spodylosing changing in my back that rheumotoid doesnt usually go to the back but it looks like I might be  I am so confused it started lupus then osteo and  now rheumotoid arthritus  I just hurt I take lyrica and skelaxin and now prednisone and caltrate What should I do
title: rheumatologist says ra 179
